results.webTitle: Keiko Fujimori claims ‘irregularities’ as rival widens narrow lead in Peru presidential election

fields.headline: Keiko Fujimori claims ‘irregularities’ as rival widens narrow lead in Peru presidential election
fields.standfirst: Far-right candidate’s statement attracts criticism as international observers say ballot passed off correctly
fields.trailText: Far-right candidate’s statement attracts criticism as international observers say ballot passed off correctly
fields.body:
Keiko Fujimori, one of the two candidates fighting vote by vote for the presidency of Peru, has alleged fraud and irregularities in the count of Sunday’s election as her rival leftist teacher Pedro Castillo widens a narrow lead.

An inter-American observer mission did not report any irregularities and said the ballot passed off correctly, complying with international standards.

With more than 96% of the official vote counted, hard-left candidate Castillo holds a razor-thin lead of about 0.2% over his far-right opponent, an advantage of nearly 100,000 votes.

But at a late press conference on Monday, Fujimori, 46, claimed there had been a “series of irregularities which worry us and we think it’s important to highlight”.

Related: Leftist teacher holds razor-thin lead in Peru presidential election

She accused Castillo’s party Perú Libre of using a strategy to “distort and delay the results which reflect the popular will” by challenging ballot tallies which, she alleged, had favoured her party Fuerza Popular.

Later on Monday night, Castillo addressed a large crowd of supporters in downtown Lima and in a tweet called on them to “defend democracy which is expressed in each one of our votes, inside and outside our beloved Peru”.

Fujimori’s remarks have attracted criticism from political figures and analysts who have described it as an act of desperation as she appears to be on the verge of losing her third election runoff in 10 years.

“It’s extremely regrettable that when the result is not favourable, that the candidate talks about fraud. It’s terrible,” Fernando Tuesta, a political science professor at Lima’s Pontifical Catholic University, told national radio broadcaster RPP on Monday night. “They have been talking about fraud because they don’t want to respect the result,” he said.

Fujimori, the daughter of the jailed former president Alberto Fujimori, narrowly lost second-round elections in 2011 against Ollanta Humala by just 3% of the vote, then in 2016 to Pedro Pablo Kuczynski by an even slimmer margin.

Related: Peru faces poll dilemma: a leftist firebrand or the dictator’s daughter?

As a candidate, Fujimori’s father – who is serving a 25-year sentence over corruption and death squad murders – and her own record as a politician play against her.

Fujimori has also racked up accusations of graft, accused of receiving more than $17m in illegal campaign funds and heading a criminal organisation, and could face a 30-year jail term if convicted. She denies the allegations, which she describes as politically motivated.

Before the ballot count began, Nicolas Saldias, Latin America and the Caribbean analyst at the Economist Intelligence Unit, predicted a tight result “could be contested amid accusations of fraud”.

“Whoever wins the election will have a very weak electoral mandate that will make governing exceptionally difficult as neither Castillo nor Fujimori has a legislative majority,” Saldias said.

The vote in the Covid-battered nation has split the country between the poor, rural Andes and the wealthier and more urban northern coast and capital Lima. It comes amid one of the worst economic slowdowns in the region, which has pushed nearly 10% of Peru’s population into poverty, millions into unemployment and prompted many others to leave major cities and return to their rural villages.

results.webTitle: Resettlement options for Biloela Tamil family are being investigated, minister says

fields.headline: Resettlement options for Biloela Tamil family are being investigated, minister says
fields.standfirst: Three-year-old Tharnicaa is being treated for sepsis after airlift from Christmas Island, family friend says
fields.trailText: Three-year-old Tharnicaa is being treated for sepsis after airlift from Christmas Island, family friend says
fields.body:
The home affairs minister has indicated the government is considering “resettlement options” for the Tamil family from Biloela detained on Christmas Island, a day after the youngest girl was airlifted to hospital for emergency medical care.

Three-year-old Tharnicaa Murugappan and her mother, Priya, were flown from Christmas Island to Perth children’s hospital on Monday after Tharnicaa had been unwell for 10 days, with a fever, vomiting, diarrhoea and dizziness.

A family friend, Angela Fredericks, told ABC News Breakfast Tharnicaa was being treated for a blood infection, sepsis, in hospital.

Related: Daughter of Biloela asylum seekers evacuated from Christmas Island for urgent medical care

“[Tharnicaa] had a chest X-ray on Christmas Island and that came back clear,” she said. “So the fight is on to find where the primary infection is, which is now feeding into the bloodstream.

“She was in a distressed state, even on the phone call, she was crying the whole time asking for her papa, so yeah, a very scary time for that little girl.”

Fredericks told AAP the infection appeared to have been caused by untreated pneumonia: “It looks like they have said she has untreated pneumonia that led to a blood infection.”

Priya, her husband, Nades, and their two Australian-born children, Kopika and Tharunicaa, were taken from the regional Queensland town of Biloela and put into detention more than 1,000 days ago, and have been held on Christmas Island since late 2019 while they challenged the government’s attempt to send them to Sri Lanka.

The family won a full federal court appeal in February, with the court upholding a ruling that the government’s handling of Tharnicaa’s visa application had denied her procedural fairness.

The federal government has not appealed the ruling but there are now two briefs before the immigration minister, Alex Hawke, to consider whether to lift the bar preventing Tharnicaa from making a visa application, and a case to release the family into community detention.

The home affairs minister, Karen Andrews, has the power to intervene at any point and allow the family to remain in Australia. Asked whether she was prepared to use those powers in relation to their situation on Tuesday, she indicated resettlement options were being examined.

“We are going through the process now of investigating a range of resettlement options in relation to a number of different circumstances here in Australia,” Andrews said. “I can’t make public commentary on that at the moment because I don’t want to disrupt those negotiations.”

The prime minister, Scott Morrison, said negotiations were under way for “all cohorts”.

According to evidence provided to Senate estimates from the department in May, the cost to detain the family on Christmas Island between August 2019 and the end of January 2021 has been $6.7m, including $2.3m in detention, food, cleaning and school costs, $1.2m for travel costs, $100,000 for medical costs, $1m for legal and translation costs, and $2.1m in staffing costs.

Last week the New Zealand government confirmed to the Guardian that “discussions are happening” between the Australian and New Zealand governments on resettling 150 refugees being held in Australia’s offshore detention system on Manus Island and Nauru. It is unclear whether the offer would be extended to those being held in immigration detention within Australia.

Fredericks said the government had questions to answer on why it had taken so long for Tharnicaa to get treatment.

“These two parents have fought so hard the last few days to get their daughter proper treatment and it’s just an absolute travesty that parents were stopped from essentially seeking the health support that they needed for their child and that has resulted in essentially now a blood infection,” she said.

“And we all know how serious sepsis is for small children especially, so I think our government and the International Medical and Health Service which services detention facilities do actually have some questions that need to be answered.”

The Department of Home Affairs issued a statement on Tuesday strongly denying any inaction in their care of Tharnicaa.

“The minor has been receiving medical treatment and daily monitoring on Christmas Island consistent with medical advice,” a spokesperson said. “This has included an IHMS general practitioner and the Christmas Island hospital.

“As soon as the ABF was advised by the treating medical practitioners that the minor required medical treatment in Western Australia, the minor was transferred to a hospital in Western Australia. The Australian Border Force strongly denies any allegations of inaction or mistreatment of individuals in its care.”

Labor has been calling for the family to be returned to Biloela in Queensland, and the shadow home affairs minister, Kristina Keneally, said on ABC News Breakfast on Tuesday Tharnicaa’s situation was “heartbreaking”.

“It’s time to bring this sorry saga, what we as a country are doing to these two little Australian-born girls to an end. Bring them home to Biloela, a town who wants and loves them.”

results.webTitle: Knowledge of medicinal plants at risk as languages die out

fields.headline: Knowledge of medicinal plants at risk as languages die out
fields.standfirst: Loss of linguistic diversity may lead to disappearance of age-old remedies unknown to science, study warns
fields.trailText: Loss of linguistic diversity means less chance to discover age-old remedies not known to science, study warns
fields.body:
Knowledge of medicinal plants is at risk of disappearing as human languages become extinct, a new study has warned.

Indigenous languages contain vast amounts of knowledge about ecosystem services provided by the natural world around them. However, more than 30% of the 7,400 languages on the planet are expected to disappear by the end of the century, according to the UN.

The impact of language extinction on loss of ecological knowledge is often overlooked, said the study’s lead researcher, Dr Rodrigo Cámara-Leret, a biologist from the University of Zurich. “Much of the focus looks at biodiversity extinction, but there is a whole other picture out there which is the loss of cultural diversity,” he said.

His team looked at 12,000 medicinal plant services associated with 230 indigenous languages in three regions with high levels of linguistic and biological diversity – North America, north-west Amazonia and New Guinea. They found that 73% of medicinal knowledge in North America was only found in one language; 91% in north-west Amazonia; and 84% in New Guinea. If the languages became extinct, the medicinal expertise associated with them probably would too. Researchers expect their findings from these regions to be similar in other parts of the world.

“The loss of language will have more critical repercussion to the extinction of traditional knowledge about medicinal plants than the loss of the plants themselves,” said Cámara-Leret.

The areas with languages most at risk were in north-west Amazonia, where 100% of this unique knowledge was supported by threatened languages, and in North America, where the figure was 86%. In New Guinea 31% of languages were at risk. The anticipated loss of linguistic diversity would “substantially compromise humanity’s capacity for medicinal discovery”, according to the paper, published in PNAS.

Related: World must rewild on massive scale to heal nature and climate, says UN

Such knowledge includes using the latex of plants to treat fungal infections, using bark to treat digestive problems, fruits for respiratory ailments, as well as natural stimulants and hallucinogens. “The list goes on and on, it’s quite impressive,” said Cámara-Leret. “Even the best plant taxonomists out there are amazed by the breadth of knowledge of indigenous cultures, not only about plants but also animals and their inter-relations.”

It is impossible to know what has already been lost. More than 1,900 of the languages spoken now have fewer than 10,000 speakers and the UN has declared 2022-32 to be the International Decade of Indigenous Languages in recognition of this issue.

Jordi Bascompte, an ecologist from Zurich University and second author of the paper, said European medicinal knowledge may represent the “tip of the iceberg”. Although a lot of drugs are based on synthetic compounds, there may be many more chemical components provided by plants that could unlock the potential for new treatments. “Any insight, regardless of where it comes from, may end up being useful,” he said.

The paper did not examine to what degree medicinal services are considered effective in the western sense, although researchers say that in many instances plants had proved effective.

Much of the world’s linguistic diversity is being safeguarded by indigenous people whose culture and livelihoods are under threat as barriers between groups are broken down. Unlike societies where information has been transcribed in books and computers, most indigenous languages transmit knowledge orally.

Governmental programmes to stimulate the transmission of languages, bilingual schooling and interest in cultural heritage would help communities retain linguistic diversity, said Cámara-Leret. But the medicinal aspect was just one of many reasons to promote the conservation and diversity of languages in the world, he added.

Dr Jonathan Loh, an anthropologist and conservationist from the University of Kent, who was not involved in the research, said he was surprised by the degree of linguistic uniqueness in medicinal plant knowledge. He has previously spoken about the parallels between linguistic and biological diversity, commenting that these had evolved in remarkably similar ways, and both faced an extinction crisis.

He said it was important, however, not to focus on utilitarian arguments for the conservation of languages, cultural diversity and biodiversity.

“There may be valuable knowledge of medicines unknown to western science contained within these languages, and doubtless that is true to some extent, but it is not the most important reason for conserving them,” he said. “Every indigenous language and culture is a unique evolutionary lineage that once lost is lost forever.”

Find more age of extinction coverage here, and follow biodiversity reporters Phoebe Weston and Patrick Greenfield on Twitter for all the latest news and features

results.webTitle: ‘Nonsense’: Victorian government demands apology after Liberals question Dan Andrews’ injury

fields.headline: ‘Nonsense’: Victorian government demands apology after Liberals question Dan Andrews’ injury
fields.standfirst: Senior ministers say opposition ‘should be ashamed’ for suggestions of a conspiracy over premier’s back injury
fields.trailText: Senior ministers say opposition ‘should be ashamed’ for suggestions of a conspiracy over premier’s back injury
fields.body:
Senior Victorian government ministers have demanded an apology from the Liberal party as the state opposition doubles down on unfounded suggestions the premier, Daniel Andrews, has covered up the circumstances of his serious back injury, and denies it is peddling conspiracy theories.

“I don’t think Dan Andrews drove the sub that took Harold Holt to China, he didn’t organise a fake moon landing,” the Victorian treasurer, Tim Pallas, said. “This is nonsense. We know it’s nonsense. It’s QAnon craziness peddled around the community to create an atmosphere of uncertainty.”

It follows the opposition treasury spokesperson, Louise Staley, issuing a press release on Monday that included a list of 12 ‘unanswered’ questions about the circumstances of Andrews’s injury.

The statement was described by Labor MPs as “vile and disgusting”.

The acting premier, James Merlino, said the opposition “should be ashamed of themselves” and backed calls for an apology.

Andrews has been off work since 9 March, when he broke several ribs and his T7 vertebra after slipping on wet steps at a holiday house on the Mornington Peninsula.

Related: Victorian opposition accused of spreading conspiracies about Dan Andrews’ injury

The 48-year-old was released from hospital on 15 March and has been recovering at home since.

There have been various unfounded rumours circulating online since his fall, including that the incident occurred at the home of businessman Lindsay Fox.

No credible evidence has been presented to support the claim, which has been denied.

Ambulance Victoria on Tuesday issued a statement saying it was called to attend to a house in Sorrento at 6.36am on 9 March, “for a patient who had fallen on steps”.

Ambulance Victoria said the information was released with the permission of the patient.

They dispatched an ambulance at normal road speed, not travelling under lights and sirens, which arrived at 7.01am.

“The patient was assessed by treating paramedics as having suspected fractured ribs, and pain relief was provided,” the statement said.

“The patient requested to attend a local hospital in order for the attending crew to remain within the area once cleared from the case. Peninsula Private Hospital Emergency Department was determined in consultation with the patient and treating paramedics. The hospital was appropriate for further investigation and treatment of the patient based on presenting symptoms and condition.”

Staley had demanded that Andrews provide details of the ambulance call-out and explain why he was initially taken to that hospital.

She defended her statement to reporters on Tuesday, saying she was asking “what lots of Victorians are asking”.

“It’s months since this happened and yet nobody’s got footage of the stairs,” she said. “Nobody’s got really any idea where it happened and this is a very visual world these days, where we seem to have everything out there on the media but not this.”

Staley denied she was peddling conspiracy theories.

“The easiest way to stop any of these conspiracy theories - which I’m not playing into - is for these questions to be answered,” she said.

The opposition leader, Michael O’Brien, defended his colleague, describing her questions as “legitimate”.

“I’m not suggesting for a second that anything the premier’s office has said about the premier’s accident or his condition is untrue. No one’s suggesting that,” he said. “It’s simply a case of we don’t necessarily know the whole truth.”

The tourism minister Martin Pakula also demanded Staley apologise to the premier.

“These sort of mad conspiracy theories are not worthy of a person who wants to be treasurer, a party that wants to be the government,” Pakula added.

Merlino said Andrews would have more to say soon on the timing of this return.

“He will be engaging with his doctors this week and will be able to give more advice, in terms of what the exact timeline will be,” he said.

results.webTitle: Police investigate alleged sexual assault of woman working at BHP’s South Flack mine in WA

fields.headline: Police investigate alleged sexual assault of woman working at BHP’s South Flack mine in WA
fields.standfirst: The alleged incident reportedly took place after the worker in her 20s was followed to her accommodation from the ‘wet mess’ at the mining camp
fields.trailText: The alleged incident reportedly took place after the worker in her 20s was followed to her accommodation from the ‘wet mess’ at the mining camp
fields.body:
Police in Western Australia are investigating an allegation that a woman working at BHP’s South Flank mine was sexually assaulted in employee accommodation.

The West Australian newspaper reported the alleged incident took place in 2020 after the woman, aged in her 20s, was followed back to her accommodation from the “wet mess” at Mulla Mulla village, the mining camp attached to the South Flank development.

A “wet mess” is a dining area where alcohol can be consumed.

Related: Aboriginal rock shelter in Pilbara damaged after BHP promised not to disturb heritage sites

The WA police minister, Paul Papalia, said he did not know of the “disturbing report” until approached by the newspaper, but police were investigating.

“I understand Sex Assault Squad detectives are investigating the matter,” he said in a statement.

“Women have the right to be safe at work and home. I encourage any victim of sexual assault to come forward to police so they can be supported and the matter investigated.”

BHP would not comment on the specific allegations but said it had a zero tolerance approach to sexual harassment and assault. About 40% of employees at South Flank are women.

“Sexual assault or harassment is unacceptable at BHP, full stop,” a BHP spokesperson said.

“We are absolutely clear on this, and all employees, contractors and those that come to our sites are made aware of their obligation to support a safe and respectful workplace.

“Any allegation of sexual assault or harassment is investigated by an independent central investigations team, and we encourage people to report any incidents that occur to authorities. If substantiated, disciplinary action is taken. Central to our response is to support the impacted person or people including through any investigation, outcomes, reporting and return to work.”

The mining company said it viewed sexual harassment and assault as a “fundamental health and safety issue”.

It said it had in recent years introduced “mandatory company-wide training dedicated to respectful behaviours, improvements to facilities such as lighting, signage and CCTV coverage, increased security presence and stricter controls on alcohol consumption”.

BHP will limit drinking at its mining camps to four standard drinks a day from July, but said that policy was introduced in line with Australian health guidelines not in response to reports of disrespectful behaviour.

People who stay at the camps are able to request a security escort to walk back to their room at night. That program has been in place for a year, BHP said, and is part of a broader push to make the camps inclusive and safe.

  • In Australia, support is available at 1800-RESPECT on 1800 737 732 or visit www.1800RESPECT.org.au.

results.webTitle: Ben Roberts-Smith defamation trial told only an ‘ostentatious psychopath’ would boast about shooting Afghan teenager

fields.headline: Ben Roberts-Smith defamation trial told only an ‘ostentatious psychopath’ would boast about shooting Afghan teenager
fields.standfirst: Lawyer for Australian soldier says allegations Roberts-Smith described shooting of teenager as ‘the most beautiful thing’ are ‘beyond ridiculous’
fields.trailText: Lawyer for Australian soldier says allegations Roberts-Smith described shooting of teenager as ‘the most beautiful thing’ are ‘beyond ridiculous’
fields.body:
Allegations Ben Roberts-Smith murdered an Afghan teenager, then boasted about shooting him as “the most beautiful thing I’ve ever seen”, were “beyond ridiculous”, his defamation trial has heard, with his lawyer describing the allegations as the acts of an “ostentatious psychopath”.

The Victoria Cross recipient’s trial has gone behind closed doors on day two, with national security-sensitive information to be discussed in camera.

Roberts-Smith, 42, is suing the Age, the Sydney Morning Herald and the Canberra Times for defamation over a series of ­reports published in 2018 which he alleges are defamatory because they portrayed him as someone who “broke the moral and legal rules of military engagement” and committed war crimes, including murder.

Roberts-Smith, a decorated former corporal in the SAS, has consistently denied the allegations as “baseless”, saying they were “completely without any foundation in truth”.

Roberts-Smith’s barrister, Bruce McClintock, returned on Tuesday morning to one murder allegation concerning the alleged killing of an Afghan adolescent who was riding in a Toyota Hilux when it was stopped by an Australian SAS patrol in 2012.

In the newspapers’ defence documents before court, they allege that “on or about 21 October 2012” Roberts-Smith was part of a patrol that stopped a Toyota Hilux carrying three Afghan men and a teenager, aged between 15 and 18 years old.

The adolescent was “searched and detained by Person 16 (an SAS soldier anonymised by the court) and then handed over to Roberts-Smith’s patrol for questioning, together with the other occupants of the Hilux”.

“At the time the Afghan adolescent was visibly extremely nervous.”

The newspapers then allege: “One or two days after the mission Person 16 said to [Roberts-Smith], in substance, ‘What happened to the young bloke who was shaking like a leaf?’

“[Roberts-Smith] responded, in substance, ‘I shot that cunt in the head. Person 15 (another soldier) told me not to kill any cunts on that job so I pulled out my 9mm and shot him in the head. It was the most beautiful thing I’ve ever seen.”

On Monday, McClintock said the allegation was “beyond ridiculous… it’s insane”.

“It’s the sort of thing that would be said by an ostentatious psychopath ... my client is not that.”

McClintock told the court the Hilux was intercepted – on a different date – by another patrol, and found to be carrying insurgents and weapons. The insurgents, he said, were detained, while the adolescent was released.

On Tuesday, McClintock argued the allegation would be cause for significant damages in Roberts-Smith’s favour because the reporters who published the allegation knew it to be false.

Since publication, it has emerged Roberts-Smith was in a different part of Afghanistan on 21 October 2012. The “on or about” date has since been amended in the newspapers’ defence to 5 November of the same year.

The newspapers were aware, McClintock argued, “that allegation was false. It follows it must have been made in bad faith.”

Also on Tuesday morning, the court heard Roberts-Smith’s burgeoning public speaking business “evaporated” after the allegations of war crimes against him were published in 2018.

In the 2017-2018 financial year, Roberts-Smith had earned about $320,000 through his public speaking and events business. Almost all his bookings were cancelled once the allegations were made public. He was also forced to abandon an offered partnership at a major accountancy firm.

The court also heard a forensic accountant estimated his future loss of earnings at $475,000.

McClintock told the trial Monday the seriousness of the allegations against Roberts-Smith, and the damage to his previously stellar reputation, “justifies the largest award of aggravated damages ever in this country”.

“The more serious the attack, the greater the amount of money to vindicate,” he said on Tuesday morning.

“Obviously, you don’t get really high damages for a trivial attack. These are not trivial attacks, these are allegations of murder and war crimes. There really can be nothing more serious than that.”

McClintock also confirmed to court that the former governor general Dame Quentin Bryce would not be appearing as a reputation witness for Roberts-Smith. McClintock had previously told the court that she would appear and give evidence.

Bryce wrote a letter of support for Roberts-Smith in 2019 but has declined to appear as a reputation witness for the former soldier.

McClintock read from an email from Bryce sent to Roberts-Smith saying “she has never withdrawn her support for Mr Roberts-Smith, but she won’t be appearing as a witness for personal reasons”.

results.webTitle: Ratko Mladić to hear final ruling on genocide conviction

fields.headline: Ratko Mladić to hear final ruling on genocide conviction
fields.standfirst:
Hague court to rule on 10 offences for which ex-Bosnian Serb commander was given life sentence in 2017

  • Ratko Mladić, the ‘warlike youth’ turned Balkan war criminal
fields.trailText: Hague court to rule on 10 offences for which ex-Bosnian Serb commander was given life sentence in 2017
fields.body:
The former Bosnian Serb commander Ratko Mladić, nicknamed the “butcher of Bosnia”, is facing a final day in court where he will hear judgment on his appeal against his conviction for genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity.

Twenty-six years after the Srebrenica massacre, Mladić, 78, will appear at the United Nations-backed international criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) in The Hague on Tuesday for what is expected to be more than an hour of rulings.

Five judges will present their conclusions on 10 offences – involving extermination, forcible transfers, terror, hostage-taking and unlawful attacks on civilians – for which Mladić was given a life sentence in 2017.

The court will also rule on the request of the UN prosecutor Serge Brammertz for a further charge of genocide to be added to the list of convictions. It will be the court’s final judgment, without recourse to further appeal.

The mothers of some of the 8,000 men and boys killed in the worst act of bloodshed on European soil since the second world war are expected to gather outside the courtroom as the verdict arrives.

The outcome of the hearing remains uncertain, although Mladić is highly unlikely to walk free. That would require three of the judges to acquit him of all the charges.

The presiding judge in the case, Prisca Matimba Nyambe, from Zambia, gave a dissenting opinion in the 2012 conviction of Zdravko Tolimir, one of seven assistant commanders who reported directly to Mladić, arguing that the evidence against him was “circumstantial”.

She has also described Mladić’s conduct around Bosnian Muslims as being kind rather than threatening at the time when the “evacuation” of the civilian population was being planned.

“That some people felt intimidated by him at these meetings, to me, is not surprising given that Mladić was a well-known general with a commanding presence in a situation of great uncertainty,” she wrote.

This week Brammertz nevertheless said he was “cautiously optimistic” about the verdict, saying he “can’t imagine another outcome than confirmation”.

Related: 'You simply die all over again': the agony of Srebrenica, 25 years on

Iva Vukušić, a historian at Utrecht University and expert on war crime trials, said it would be important for the survivors for there to be a unanimous judgment.

She said: “This is really one of its most important trials, and it has been 25 years in the making. If they do convict but the presiding judge dissents really on the very substance of what happened then it’s less grave, he still goes to prison, but for a judgment it makes it weaker if the presiding judge says they fundamentally disagree. Then the nationalists have a field day saying: ‘Look they convicted him, but even the presiding judge didn’t believe it.’”

Mladić, who spent a decade on the run before his capture in 2011 in northern Serbia, was the chief of staff of Bosnian Serb forces from 1992 until 1996, during the civil war and ethnic cleansing that followed the breakup of the Yugoslav state.

Almost 600 people gave evidence for the prosecution and defence during the original four-year trial. Delivering the verdicts, the presiding judge, Alphons Orie, said the crimes ranked “among the most heinous known to humankind and include genocide and extermination”.

results.webTitle: Victoria’s Covid restrictions ‘on track’ to ease from Friday as two cases recorded

fields.headline: Victoria’s Covid restrictions ‘on track’ to ease from Friday as two cases recorded
fields.standfirst: Delta strain of Covid-19 identified in Melbourne cases linked to traveller who returned from Sri Lanka and entered hotel quarantine on 8 May
fields.trailText: Delta strain of Covid-19 identified in Melbourne cases linked to traveller who returned from Sri Lanka and entered hotel quarantine on 8 May
fields.body:
Victorians are “on track” to enjoy eased Covid restrictions from Friday, the acting premier, James Merlino, has said, with the two new cases announced in the state on Tuesday linked to existing cases.

Health authorities also revealed that genomic sequencing has linked the Delta strain of Covid-19 that spread in West Melbourne to a traveller who returned from Sri Lanka and entered hotel quarantine on 8 May.

While he tested positive in hotel quarantine and was moved to a health hotel on 9 May before finishing quarantine on 23 May, authorities are puzzled as to how the man in his 40s transmitted the virus to other cases in the West Melbourne cluster.

The man lives in the Glen Eira LGA, in Melbourne’s southeast, and the other 23 passengers on his flight, aircrew, Skybus crew, and hundreds of staff from both hotels linked to the man have tested negative.

Related: Australia news live: Victoria finds source of Delta Covid outbreak; Biloela child reportedly diagnosed with pneumonia

“I can confirm that so far there is no reported or obvious breach of infection prevention control protocols or anything else that would indicate a transmission has happened inside the hotel,” Danny Pearson, acting police and emergency services minister, said.

Allen Cheng, Victoria’s deputy chief health officer, said of four theories authorities are exploring about how Covid spread from the man, the “most likely” was that he transmitted the virus to another hotel guest or to a staff member when being transferred to the Holiday Inn health hotel.

Of the two new cases announced on Tuesday, one is a child linked to the West Melbourne Delta variant cluster, and the other is a household contact of a worker linked to the Kappa variant outbreak at the Arcare Maidstone aged care facility.

Merlino said both of the new cases have had limited community exposure, as they were primary contacts of known cases.

While flagging an easing of restrictions to take effect from Friday, Merlino said public health advice meant that travel between metropolitan Melbourne and regional Victoria would continue to be restricted over the long weekend.

“That will extend beyond any announcements that we will make later in the week. There are very good reasons for that. We absolutely want to run this into ground and ensure that there’s no risk of this spreading out into regional Victoria. We wanted to be up-front and honest with people at the earliest opportunity.

Related: Australians have been forgiving of the government’s Covid response, but we may have reached our limit | Peter Lewis

“I don’t want to foreshadow what we are going to announce. We are still...working through all the elements. It is a day-by-day, hour by hour analysis about how we are tracking … We remain on track to provide that easing of restrictions to all Victorians,” Merlino said.

There are now 85 local cases of Covid-19 in Victoria.

Asked if the genomic discovery of the Delta variant’s origins constituted a failure of hotel quarantine, Merlino reiterated the shortcomings of hotel design and how his state has been pursuing a purpose-built quarantine facility.

Related: Where did Australia’s first cases of the Covid Delta variant come from and how infectious is it?

“We are making it as risk-free as humanely possible but it has never ever been a zero-risk environment. That is not the nature of hotels. Hotels are built for tourists. They’re not built to tackle infectious disease,” Merlino said.

He also said that any purpose-built quarantine facility would act alongside hotel quarantine, and could be used to support higher risk returned travellers.

Merlino was also scathing of the Victorian opposition’s demand for premier Daniel Andrews to release details of his back injury, saying the state Liberal party “should be ashamed of themselves”.

Ambulance Victoria issued a statement with details of Andrews’ fall on Tuesday morning, and Merlino backed calls for the opposition to apologise.

“You can’t put to bed conspiracy nutters and if the Liberal party want to act disgracefully, that is a matter for them,” Merlino said.

While flagging an easing of restrictions to take effect from Friday, Merlino said public health advice meant that travel between metropolitan Melbourne and regional Victoria would continue to be restricted over the long weekend. “That will extend beyond any announcements that we will make later in the week. There are very good reasons for that. We absolutely want to run this into ground and ensure that there’s no risk of this spreading out into regional Victoria. We wanted to be up-front and honest with people at the earliest opportunity. “I don’t want to foreshadow what we are going to announce. We are still...working through all the elements. It is a day-by-day, hour by hour analysis about how we are tracking … We remain on track to provide that easing of restrictions to all Victorians,” Merlino said. There are now 85 local cases of Covid-19 in Victoria. Asked if the genomic discovery of the Delta variant’s origins constituted a failure of hotel quarantine, Merlino reiterated the shortcomings of hotel design and how his state has been pursuing a purpose-built quarantine facility. “We are making it as risk-free as humanely possible but it has never ever been a zero-risk environment. That is not the nature of hotels. Hotels are built for tourists. They’re not built to tackle infectious disease,” Merlino said. He also said that any purpose-built quarantine facility would act alongside hotel quarantine, and could be used to support higher risk returned travellers. Merlino was also scathing of the Victorian opposition’s demand for premier Daniel Andrews to release details of his back injury, saying the state Liberal party “should be ashamed of themselves”. Ambulance Victoria issued a statement with details of Andrews’ fall on Tuesday morning, and Merlino backed calls for the opposition to apologise. “You can’t put to bed conspiracy nutters and if the Liberal party want to act disgracefully, that is a matter for them,” Merlino said.
